photo.title: Telegraph Hill and the Financial District from San Francisco Bay, Ca. USA

description._content:
This view from offshore highlights why the 87m asl hill between Fisherman's Wharf (Pier 39 is at the right of the foreground) and the Financial District (in the background) was first developed in 1850, when a semaphore signalling station was established to report on the arrival of ships.  Within three years it had been replaced by an electric telegraph station, which itself soon fell out of use, though the 'Telegraph Hill' name stuck.  The site was purchased by local businessmen in 1876 specifically to prevent further development; they donated the land to the city on condition that it became a park.  Aside from being an obvious choice for the location of the 64m-tall Lillian Coit Memorial Tower, opened in 1933, Pioneer Park is also known for its resident wild parrots.

Needless to say, the buildings of the Financial District were somewhat smaller in 1850; the 'Manhattanization' of San Francisco didn't occur until the 1960s and 70s.  The skyline features four successively holders of the record for 'tallest building in California' (and hence tallest west of west of the Mississippi) 1964-74: at 142 m, the Hartford Building at 650 California St. was tallest when built in 1964, but surrendered the title to the 172 m 44 Montgomery (once the world headquarters for Wells Fargo Bank) on its completion in 1967.  555 California Street, still the second tallest building in the city and largest by floor area, reached 237 m in 1969, but was overtaken by the dramatic 260 m Transamerica Pyramid in 1972. That in turn is now 'merely' the tallest in the city and in the top 200 worldwide.
The city's third tallest, incidentally, is the twin-towered 345 California Center, 189 m tall to roof level but 220 m if the spires are included.

description._content:
50/365

Today I had a pretty cool gig shooting a corporate portrait for a senior VP of a major bank here in the city. This was the view from the office I was shooting  in. 

So many many  windows of opportunity.  I must keep thinking positive

photo.title: One Sansome Street is the Anglo and London Paris National Bank building by Albert Pissis (1910)

description._content: via Wiki: The bank building was granite clad with 38 ft (12 m) high Doric columns. The historic architecture of the bank building serves as a conservatory.
